newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX electricity prices mostly ease in mild temps.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX electricity prices mostly ease in mild temps.

text.p: NYMEX electricity futures were trading mostly lower Monday on returning power generation units and forecasts of below-normal temperatures in the U.S. West, industry sources said.

As of 1245 EDT, July Palo Verde (PV) was trading down 13 cents at the day's high of $27.50 per megawatt hour (MWh) after exchanges as low as $27.25, while August was down 30 cents at the day's low of $30.50 following trade as high as $30.60 per MWh.

July California Oregon Border (COB) was down one cent at $17.20 following exchanges in a range of $17.10-17.30, while August was steady at the day's high of $21.70 after trade as low as $21.65 per MWh.
September through November COB were trading steady to five cents higher.
NYMEX said as of 1205 an estimated total of 267 COB and 231 PV contracts had traded.
Generation units in the West were being returned to service from spring maintenance and refueling outages.
Over the weekend, two 550 megawatt (MW) coal-fired units in Wyoming, one at the Jim Bridger plant and one at Laramie River Station, were restarted after maintenance outages.

Also, the 1,221 MW unit 2 at Palo Verde nuclear station in Arizona was operatng at 90 percent of capacity as of early Tuesday during unplanned repairs to a main feedwater heater leak, which were expected to finish early Tuesday.

Southwest forecasts called for generally fair and dry conditions through Thursday with temperatures expected to be two to six degrees below normal. Clouds, showers and thunderstorms were possible across the region later in the week.
The Pacific Northwest was expected to see temperatures near to slightly below normal through to the early weekend, with scattered showers and thunderstorms during the period.
NYMEX July Henry Hub natural gas futures were trading down 0.5 cents at $2.135 per million British thermal units as of 1245 EDT.
COB open interest for June 9 rose 102 to 6,777, while PV open interest was off three to 6,462, NYMEX said.
